conclusion: Analyzing the circuit both when the switch is open and closed to determine the electric power consumed by the circuit when the switch is closed and compare it to 15 W.
The circuit diagram shows a voltage source, an ammeter in series, a resistor R1 = 20 Ω in series with a motor M with internal resistance R2 = 10 Ω, and a switch in parallel with the motor.
When the switch is open, the current flows through the ammeter, R1, and the motor M (with internal resistance R2). The ammeter reading is I0 = 0.5 A.
The total resistance in the circuit when the switch is open is R_total, open = R1 + R2 = 30 Ω.
The voltage U across the circuit when the switch is open is U = I0 × R_total, open = 15 V.
The supply voltage U = 15 V remains unchanged when the switch is closed.
When the switch is closed, the switch is in parallel with the motor M, effectively short-circuiting the motor.
The current flows through the ammeter, R1, and the switch, bypassing the motor M.
The total resistance in the circuit when the switch is closed is R_total, closed = R1 = 20 Ω.
The current I in the circuit when the switch is closed is I = U / R1 = 0.75 A.
The motor starts to rotate when the switch is closed, which seems contradictory because the motor is short-circuited.
Short-circuiting a motor would prevent it from operating, as no voltage would drop across it to drive it.
This might be a theoretical question where 'rotation' implies a different context.
A common setup is that the motor has a back EMF when it rotates, but since the motor is shorted, no current flows through it.
Assume the motor's rotation is mentioned to indicate it’s not consuming power in this state.
The electric power P consumed by the circuit when the switch is closed is P = U × I = 11.25 W.
Alternatively, the power dissipated in the circuit is P = I^2 × R1 = 11.25 W.
Both methods agree, confirming P = 11.25 W.
The power consumed by the circuit is less than 15 W.
